question: <image 1> A company wants to evaluate its attrition rate, in other words, how long new hires stay with the company. Over the years, they have established the following probability distribution. Let X = the number of years a new hire will stay with the company. Let P(x) = the probability that a new hire will stay with the company x years. P(x = 4) = _______
description:
The image displays a table representing a probability distribution for the number of years a new hire will stay with a company. The table has two columns: one labeled "x" and the other labeled "P(x)." 

- The "x" column lists the number of years a new hire stays with the company, ranging from 0 to 6.
- The "P(x)" column lists the corresponding probabilities for each value of x.

Here are the values provided in the table:

| x | P(x) |
|---|------|
| 0 | 0.12 |
| 1 | 0.18 |
| 2 | 0.30 |
| 3 | 0.15 |
| 4 |      |
| 5 | 0.10 |
| 6 | 0.05 |

The probability for x = 4 is missing in the table. To find P(x = 4), you would need to use the fact that the sum of all probabilities in a probability distribution must equal 1. Therefore, you can calculate P(x = 4) by subtracting the sum of the given probabilities from 1.
